awd_titl_txt: RELAMPAGO Hydrometeorology Component:  Land Surface Controls on Heavy Precipitation and Flooding in the Carcarana River Basin, Argentina
awd_abstract_narration:
Hydrometeorological impacts from organized, continental warm season convection are some of the most disastrous and costly of weather-related impacts. Globally, each year, these severe weather events cause intense rainfall, hailstorms, tornadoes, flash floods, and landslides which in turn result in significant crop losses, property damage, urban hazards and loss of human life. Despite the enormous impact such events have on society, the mechanisms driving intense, organized convection and the coupled hydrological responses from those events are not well understood.  In this work, we will perform an observational field campaign and coupled modeling study using focused on warm season convection in the Carcarañá River basin in Argentina. The geographical focus on this region stems from the fact that some of the world's deepest and largest convective storms develop at the foothills of the Sierras de Córdoba - a mountain range east of the Andes which is the headwaters of the Carcarañá. Compared to the Great Plains of the United States, convective organization and propagation in subtropical South America is more frequent and confined to a much smaller region - which causes the Carcarañá river basin to be continuously affected by these severe storms, confines the spatial extent of the observational studies and increases the probability of capturing extreme events during a field campaign.

The study leverages from and complements the multi-institutional RELAMPAGO/CACTI effort. The observational and modeling work is approached from two perspectives. The first investigates how the land surface impacts the initiation and growth of convective precipitation (atmospheric perspective). The second investigates if changes in land cover have affected the hydrologic cycle and the probability of flooding in the basin (hydrology perspective). The impact of this work is threefold: it addresses fundamental scientific questions in hydrometeorology, drives improvements in fully-coupled hydrometeorological models and ultimately improves predictive skill of high impact weather events.

This work combines an integrated hydrometeorological field campaign and coupled modeling study using the WRF/WRF-Hydro system focused on the Carcarañá River basin in Argentina. This basin drains east from the Sierras de Cordoba, a mesoscale mountain range east of the Andes, toward the plains. Frequently impacted by severe, organized convection, the Carcarañá basin is ideally suited to perform observational and modeling studies aimed at understanding the role of the land surface in modulating the observed variability of intense convective systems and associated precipitation and flooding.

The overarching science question of this work is: What is the role of the land surface in modulating the observed variability of heavy precipitation and flooding in the Carcarañá River Basin? We address this overarching question with two subsidiary questions: 
1. How does land cover heterogeneity (including human-modified land cover) impact initiation and growth of convective precipitation at the local and meso-scale through land-atmosphere exchanges of moisture and energy?
2. How have changes in land cover affected the partitioning of rainfall between infiltration/runoff and the residence times of soil moisture and groundwater in the Carcarañá Basin's terrestrial system?

The tools we will use are: a) Existing local observations of precipitation, water table depths and streamflow, b) Observations of precipitation, streamflow, soil moisture, temperature and surface fluxes measured by our team during the RELAMPAGO field campaign, c) Numerical simulations using the fully-coupled WRF/WRF-hydro modeling system both in offline mode (i.e. WRF-Hydro only, driven by observed meteorological conditions) and coupled (WRF/WRF-Hydro) modes. Our study region has many similarities with the Great Plains of the United States in terms of the importance of land-atmosphere interactions, the initiation and upscale growth of MCSs and the importance of low-level jet moisture transport. Hence, improved understanding of the hydrometeorology of MCSs will have far-reaching benefits beyond Argentina.

por.por_cntn:
The RELAMPAGO Hydromet project led a coordinated hydrometeorological field campaign in Argentina and a modeling effort, which resulted in 1) new discoveries on the impact of land cover change on the hydroclimatology of the region 2) better understanding and predictability of streamflow response to convective precipitation events in mountainous catchments 3) deep and long-lasting engagement with Argentinian Scientists, Stakeholders and Communities 4) Training of the next generation of hydrometeorologists. Below I will describe the outcomes of the project in detail.


1) Changes in Land Cover have changed the Hydroclimate of Southeastern South America 

Since the 1970s, land cover in central Argentina has shifted away from perennial crops and grasses toward annual crops, largely soy. Using observations and modeling, we show that these changes have dramatically changed the surface/subsurface and atmospheric branches of the hydrologic cycle. In the past, most of the precipitation was re-evaporated to the atmosphere by perennial grasses. Now, there is less evpotranspiration, more infiltration and this results in rising water tables and increased streamflow and flooding.


Observations: Our team, led by NCAR scientists, installed a network of 30 meteorological stations throughout the Cordoba region of Argentina. Seven flux towers, ten disdrometers, two microradars, and two groundwater observations. We have approximately 10 months of data from the stations from June 2018 ? April 2019. 


Modeling: To better understand the long-term temporal behavior from 1970s to present, we use the Noah-MP land surface model calibrated at both soy and alfalfa sites.

Pal et al. 2021, Water Resources Research

Pal 2021. UIUC


2) Streamflow Response to Convective Precipitation events in Mountainous Catchments of Southeastern South America

By installing streamflow observations in previously ungauged basins, we show for the first time, that the streamflow response time to convective precipitation events in the upper basin of the Carcara?a is typically between 6-8 hours. In conjunction WRF and WRF-Hydro modeling we highlight that streamflow simulations using the ensemble forecasting with data assimilation provide realistic flash flood forecast in terms of timing and magnitude of the peak. This system could be used in other regions of the world. 


Observations: Our team, led by collaborators from the Universidad de Cordoba and the ministry of Water from the Province of Cordoba installed eight stream level sensors throughout the Carcara?? basin in previously ungauged basins. These sensors are still collecting data. During the 6-week RELAMPAGO IOP (Nov-Dec 2018) the HYDROMET team deployed observations for 10 campaigns. Using these observations, we were able to fully characterize the rating curves for the upper basin of the Tercero.

Modeling: We modeled the hydrology of the upper Carcara?? Basin using WRF and WRF-Hydro as a system for hindcast, deterministic forecast and a 40-member ensemble forecast initialized with regional-scale atmospheric data assimilation.


Pal et al. 2021, J.  Hydrometeorology

Nesbitt et al. 2021, BAMS


3) Engagement with Argentinian Scientists, Stakeholders and Communities

Collaborations with U. Cordoba's team of Professor Marcelo Garcia were critical for RELAMPAGO's continuing success. Many of RELAMPAGO HYDROMET's achievements were possible because of their scientific expertise in streamflow measurements using LSPIV and ADCP, help with importation and installation of meteorological stations, outreach to K-12 schools, and links to the community and local authorities. RELAMPAGO has helped inform water managers in the region by aiding dam operations, and created collaborations between Argentinian forecasters and water managers.
The MATTEO project, led by Professor Marcelo Garcia, has been the K-12 educational outreach component of RELAMPAGO. Children and young people in 50+ schools carry out hydrological and hydrometeorological measurements and build their own low-cost instruments.  Through MATTEO, the RELAMPAGO team participated in outreach to local schools. 
As a result of the RELAMPAGO field campaign in Argentina. Two elementary school teachers wrote two children's books based on our work. The first book `Field Work, Ayla's Adventures on Earth' imagines an extra-terrestrial being traveling with the moisture from the Atlantic through the Amazon Forest towards the south and falling as rain in Argentina. The second book `The Guardian', for young adults, is based on the work published in Water Resources Research (Pal et al. 2021). It follows the story of two immigrant brothers that arrive in Illinois and Argentina and narrates their relation to agriculture and their environment. 
Vicario et al.. (2020).  

Manassero, (2020). Trabajo de campo.

Manassero, (2021). El guardian.


4) Training

RELAMPAGO funded the PhD of Sujan Pal, and provided both Sujan Pal and Carolina Bieri field campaign experience. RELAMPAGO provided funds for NCAR scientists: David Gochis, Justin Lentz, Andy Gaydos and Erin Dougherty. The project has also provided significant opportunities for UIUC and Argentinian students and PIs to interact with the different teams (NCAR EOL, NCAR RAL and all the RELAMPAGO scientists). PI Dominguez was awarded the AGU Ascent Award (2019) and the AMS Robert E. Horton Lecture (2022) in part based on work funded by RELAMPAGO.
